question: Question_03_(d)
statement:
Full-Solution Problem. Justify your answers and show all your work.
Simplification of answers is not required.

 Evaluate the following integral.

$\int (\cos^{3} x)(\sin^{4} x)\, dx$
sols:
Notice that

\begin{align*}
\int (\cos^{3} x)(\sin^{4} x)\, dx &= \int (\cos^{2} x)(\sin^{4} x)\cos x \, dx \\
&=  \int (1-\sin^{2} x ))(\sin^{4} x)\cos x \, dx
\end{align*}

So let $u = \sin x$ so $du = (\cos x)dx$. Thus,

\begin{align*}
\int (\cos^{3} x)(\sin^{4} x)\, dx &=  \int (1-\sin^{2} x ))(\sin^{4} x)\cos x \, dx \\
&= \int (1-u^{2} ))u^{4} \, du \\ 
&= \int u^{4}-u^{6} \, du \\
&= \frac{u^{5}}{5} - \frac{u^{7}}{7} +C\\
&= \frac{\sin^{5} x}{5} - \frac{\sin^{7} x}{7}  +C
\end{align*}

completing the question.
hints: The power of cosine is odd. Peel off a power then try a substitution.
